moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. g3: this is called the Catalan opening, it seems passive but can become exciting with moves like Bb4+
moves.3... c5: Black is trying to contest whites strong centre pawns.
moves.4. d5 Bd6: this move is both good and bad, it is blocking the D-pawn but if 5.dxe6, dxe6 then white cant come down with 6.Qxd8+ causing the king to be forced to move.
moves.5. Bg2 h6 6. Nf3 O-O 7. Nc3 a6 8. Be3 b5: in my opinion, better was the more aggressive 8...Ng4.
moves.9. cxb5 exd5 10. Nxd5 axb5 11. Nc3 b4: this is a blunder, the queen can take the B on d6 and although black has bxc3 to win back the piece the pawn on c3 can be recaptured and black is down a pawn.
moves.12. Nb1: this move is not a disaster for white but wastes a lot of time.
moves.12... Na6: this is a clear blunder, black is dropping a piece.
moves.13. Qxd6 Qa5 14. Bxh6: this move looks nice because of gxh6, Qxf6 but black did not see b3+
moves.14... Ne4 15. Qd5 b3+: now black sees the move but it is not of as much use.
moves.16. Bd2 Nxd2 17. Nfxd2 Rb8 18. O-O Bb7: black sacrifices another pawn but is skewering through the Q and B.
moves.19. Qxd7 Bxg2 20. Kxg2 Rfd8: the key to playing when behind is not being passive, which black has done. although bxa2 was probably better.
moves.22... Rxd2 23. Rxa2 Qb6 24. Rfa1 Nb4: if this game were continued from this point by two very high rated players e.g. 2400, it would definitely be a win for white. but at 1600 level 2 pawns wont make much difference, one mistake can easily change the game.
moves.25. Ra2a8 Qb7+ 26. f3: f3 is a game-changing mistake, instead Qe4 would have blocked the check and defended the rook on a8.
moves.26... Rxa8 27. Rxa8+ Qxa8 28. Qxc5 Nd5 2: this game is now certainly going blacks way.
moves.31. b4 Qd5 32. Qc8+ Kh7 33. Qg4 Qe6: at this point white resigns. apart from a few blunders it was well played by both players.
